conclusion: To determine how the shadows labeled A, B, and C will change when the light source moves to the right above the objects, we need to consider the principles of shadow formation.
Shadows are created when an object blocks light from a source, and their position and size depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface.
The image shows three objects casting shadows labeled A, B, and C.
Object corresponding to shadow A: A birdcage (top left).
Object corresponding to shadow B: A small cylindrical object (top right).
Object corresponding to shadow C: A drumstick or similar object (bottom left).
The current light source appears to be positioned somewhere above and slightly to the left of the objects, as the shadows are cast to the right and downward.
The shadow of an object is cast in the direction opposite to the light source relative to the object.

premise: If the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left.
conclusion: When the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left.
The size of the shadow depends on the angle of the light rays.

premise: When the light source moves closer to being directly above the object, the shadow tends to shrink because the light rays become more parallel, reducing the spread.
conclusion: If the light source moves directly above the objects, the shadows will shrink.

premise: Conversely, if the light source moves farther to the side, the shadow can elongate due to the increased angle of incidence.
conclusion: If the light source moves farther to the side, the shadow can elongate.
The light source is now to the right above the objects.

premise: The light rays will come from the right side, causing the shadows to shift to the left.
conclusion: The shadows will shift to the left.

premise: Shadow A (from the birdcage) will move to the left of its current position.
conclusion: Shadow A will move to the left.

premise: Shadow B (from the cylindrical object) will move to the left of its current position.
conclusion: Shadow B will move to the left.

premise: Shadow C (from the drumstick) will move to the left of its current position.
conclusion: Shadow C will move to the left.
